introduction.p: Now that we have a new number, let's let it out to play in the field with all the other numbers.

subsection.title: Definition of the field

statement.p:
Suppose we have polynomial x^2 - 6x + 13. Is the number 3+2\ci a root? To check, substitute x = 3+2\ci .
\amp \phantom{=} (3+2\ci)^2 - 6(3+2\ci) + 13
\amp = (9 + 12\ci + 4(-1)) - 18 - 12\ci + 13 \amp \amp (\ci^2 = -1)
\amp = 0.
The answer is yes! By algebraically combining \ci, which is a root of the prototypical unsolvable polynomial equation x^2+1=0, with other real numbers, we obtain roots of other previously unsolvable polynomial equations.

subsection.p: It turns out that the result of combining such expressions involving \ci using the four operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division can always be simplified using \ci^2 = -1 down to something of the form a + b\ci, where a,b are real numbers.

statement.p: The collection \C of all possible algebraic expressions a+b\ci, where a,b are real numbers. Expressions of this form are called complex numbers. In such an expression, the number a is called the real part complexnumbersreal part realpart of a complex number and the number b is called the imaginary partcomplexnumbersimaginary partimaginarypart of a complex number.

dl.li: \Re(z) The real part of the complex number z.
\Im(z) The imaginary part of the complex number z.

ul.li: The complex number -3+\frac{1}{2}\ci has real part \Re\left(-3+\frac{1}{2}\ci\right)=-3 and imaginary part \Im\left(-3+\frac{1}{2}\ci\right)=\frac{1}{2}.
The complex number e - \pi\ci = e + (-\pi)\ci has real part \Re(e - \pi\ci) = e and imaginary part \Im(e - \pi\ci) = -\pi.

remark.title: Real numbers are complex numbers
remark.p: Every real number a can simultaneously be considered to be a complex number, as a = a + 0\ci. So the real numbers are precisely those complex numbers that have imaginary part equal to zero. (Complex numbers whose real part is equal to zero are called purely imaginaryimaginarynumberpurely. For example, 3\ci is purely imaginary.)

subsection.p: Roughly speaking, a fieldfieldof abstract numbers is a mathematical system of numbers that carries some versions of the four operations addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division, and in which these four operations behave arithmetically and algebraically the way we would expect them to behave. We explore these four operations for the complex numbers, along with an important new fifth operation, in the following subsections.

subsection.title: Basic operations with complex numbers
subsection.p: Here are examples of adding, subtracting, multiplying, and exponentiating complex numbers. (We will deal with division afterward.) Notice it mostly involves just familiar algebra: collecting like terms and FOIL.

The last in the list of examples above is particularly important. You may recognize it as related to the factorization of a difference of squares. Since \ci^2 = -1, multiplying a complex number against its difference-of-squares-factorization partner like this always results in a real number. Because of this, we'll give this partner a name.

statement.p: For complex number z = a + b\ci, we define the complex conjugate of z to be \cconj{z} = \lcconj{a+b\ci} = a - b\ci.

remark.p: You should think of complex conjugate as flipping the sign on the imaginary part of the complex number. In particular, if z = a - b\ci then \cconj{z} = \lcconj{a - b\ci} = a + b\ci.

subsection.title: Division of complex nubers
subsection.p: We can use complex conjugates to help us divide complex numbers.

paragraphs.title: Pattern

subsection.p: Since we can divide, we can also reciprocate.

statement.p:
Let's compute the reciprocal of 3+2\ci. \inv{(3+2\ci)} = \frac{1}{3+2\ci} = \frac{1+0\ci}{3+2\ci} \cdot \frac{3-2\ci}{3-2\ci} = \frac{3}{13} - \frac{2}{13}\, \ci. If we multiply a number and its reciprocal, we would expect to get 1 as the result.
(3+2\ci)\inv{(3+2\ci)} \amp = (3+2\ci)\left(\frac{3}{13} - \frac{2}{13}\, \ci\right)
\amp = \frac{9}{13} - \frac{6}{13}\, \ci + \frac{6}{13}\, \ci - \frac{4}{13} \cdot (-1)
\amp = 1 + 0 \ci
\amp = 1.
It worked!

subsection.p: There is a pattern to this reciprocal example, but it will have to wait until after .

subsection.title: Properties of complex numbers
subsection.p: Since the operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of complex numbers are built on following our usual algebra rules on expressions involving the variable \ci (along with the extra rule \ci^2 = -1), there is no need to restate all those usual algebra rules. So we will focus on the new operation of complex conjugation.

statement.p:
The following are valid rules of algebra involving the complex conjugation operation. Let w and z represent arbitrary complex numbers, and let k represent an arbitrary real number.
Conjugating a real number has no effect. That is, \cconj{k} = k.
The conjuate of a sum is the sum of the conjugates. That is, \lcconj{w+z} = \cconj{w} + \cconj{z}.
The conjugate of a product is the product of the conjugates. That is, \lcconj{wz} = \cconj{w}\cconj{z}.
The conjugate of a scalar multiple is the scalar multiple of the conjugate. That is, \lcconj{kz} = k\cconj{z}.
The conjugate of a quotient is the quotient of the conjugates. That is, \lcconj{w/z} = \cconj{w} / \cconj{z}.
The conjugate of a reciprocal is the reciprocal of the conjugate. That is, \lcconj{1/z} = 1 / \cconj{z}.
For every nonzero, integer exponent, the conjugate of that power is the power of the conjugate. That is, \lcconj{z^n} = \cconj{z}^n.

subsection.p: Considering how a complex number interacts with its own conjugate yields several important patterns.

statement.p:
A complex number z satisfies the following special relationships with its own conjugate.
The conjugate of a conjugate is the original complex number. That is, \lcconj{\cconj{z}} = z.
A complex number is actually real ( has imaginary part 0) if and only if it is equal to its own conjugate. That is, z is real if and only if \cconj{z} = z.
A complex number is purely imaginary ( has real part 0) if and only if it is equal to the negative of its own conjugate. That is, z is purely imaginary if and only if \cconj{z} = -z.
Combining a complex number with its conjugate using addition or subtraction returns twice the real part or twice the imaginary part times \ci, respectively. That is,
z + \cconj{z} \amp = 2\cdot\Re(z), \amp z - \cconj{z} = 2\cdot\Im(z)\cdot\ci.
Multiplying a complex number and its complex conjugate always results in a real number, equal to the sum of the squares of the real and imaginary parts. That is, if z = a + b\ci, then z\cconj{z} = a^2 + b^2.

subsection.p:
The sum-of-squares pattern in Statement of
has a connection to geometry via Pythagoras that we will explore in . (And by the time you are reading this appendix, you may already have encountered the sum-of-squares formula's connection to geometry in a linear algebra context in .) For now, we will give a version of this formula a name.

statement.p: For complex number z = a + b\ci, the real number \cmodulus{z} = \sqrt{a^2 + b^2} is called the modulus complexmodulus modulus (of a complex number) of z.

The following are valid rules of algebra involving the complex modulus. Let w and z represent arbitrary complex numbers, and let k represent an arbitrary real number.
The square of the modulus is equal to the product of the complex number with its own conjugate. That is, \cmodulus{z}^2 = z\cconj{z}.
A modulus is never negative, and only zero has modulus zero. That is, \cmodulus{z} \ge 0, with \cmodulus{z} = 0 if and only if z=0.
A complex number and its conjugate have the same modulus. That is, \cmodulus{\cconj{z}} = \cmodulus{z}.
The modulus of a real number is equal to the absolute value of that number.
The modulus of a product is the product of the moduli. That is, \cmodulus{wz} = \cmodulus{w}\cmodulus{z}.
The modulus of a scalar multiple is the absolute scalar multiple of the modulus. That is, \cmodulus{kz} = \abs{k}\cmodulus{z}, where \abs{k} is the regular absolute value of the real number k.
The modulus of a quotient is the quotient of the moduli. That is, \cmodulus{w/z} = \cmodulus{w}/\cmodulus{z}.
The modulus of a reciprocal is the reciprocal of the modulus. That is, \cmodulus{1/z} = 1/\cmodulus{z}.
For every nonzero, integer exponent, the modulus of that power is the power of the modulus. That is, \cmodulus{z^n} = \cmodulus{z}^n.
The modulus satisfies the Triangle Inequality: \cmodulus{w + z} \le \cmodulus{w} + \cmodulus{z}.

paragraphs.title: Pattern
paragraphs.p:
We can use Statement of
to help us reciprocate:
\cmodulus{z}^2 \amp = z\cconj{z} \amp \amp \implies \amp \inv{z} \amp = \frac{\cconj{z}}{\cmodulus{z}^2}.

example.title: Reciprocal of a complex number, revisited

statement.p: We have \cmodulus{3+2\ci}^2 = 3^2 + 2^2 = 13, and so \inv{(3+2\ci)} = \frac{\lcconj{3+2\ci}}{\cmodulus{3+2\ci}^2} = \frac{3-2\ci}{13} = \frac{3}{13} - \frac{2}{13}\, \ci, which is the same reciprocal as previously calculated in .

subsection.title: Complex polynomials

introduction.p: The most important property of the field of complex numbers is that by merely inventing a solution to one previously unsolvable polynomial equation ( the imaginary solution \ci to x^2 + 1 = 0), we have actually created solutions to all polynomial equations.

subsection.p: Now that we know how to perform arithmetic with complex numbers, we can expand to doing some algebra. A complex polynomial complexpolynomial is just a polynomial where we allow the coefficients to be complex numbers, and assume the variable to represent an unknown complex number.

example.title: Checking a solution to a complex polynomial

statement.p:
Is z = 4-\ci a solution to the complex polynomial equation z^2 + \ci z + (-16+4\ci)=0?
\amp \phantom{=} (4-\ci)^2 + \ci (4-\ci) + (-16+4\ci) \amp = \bigl[16 - 8\ci + (-1)\bigr] + \bigl[4\ci - (-1)\bigr] + (-16+4\ci) \amp = 0.
Yes, z = 4-\ci is a solution to z^2 + \ci z + (-16+4\ci).

theorem.title: The Fundamental Theorem of Algebra (Complex Version)

statement.p: If p(z) is a complex polynomial of degree n \ge 1, then the polynomial equation p(z) = 0 has exactly n roots (where repeated roots are counted multiple times, according to the number of times that root is repeated).

subsection.p: Because determining roots of a polynomial is equivalent to factoring that polynomial, we can reinterpret this theorem in terms of factoring.

statement.p: Every complex polynomial p(z) can be completely factored as p(z) = w_0 (z-w_1)(z-w_2) \dotsm (z-w_n), for some constant complex numbers w_0,w_1,w_2,\dotsc,w_n, where n is the degree of p(z).

subsection.p: We can also use this complex version of the Fundamental Theorem to refine the real version (), since a real polynomial can be considered to be a complex polynomial that just happens to have purely real numbers as coefficients.

statement.p: If p(x) is a real polynomial of degree n \ge 1, then the polynomial equation p(x) = 0 has exactly n roots when we allow complex numbers as roots (and where again, repeated roots are counted multiple times).

Consider the cubic polynomial equation
x^3 + 3x^2 + 2x - 6 = 0.
We can guess one root: x=1 solves this equation. This means that x-1 is a factor of this polynomial. Using long division of polynomials, we could calculate \frac{x^3 + 3x^2 + 2x - 6}{x-1} = x^2+4x+6, so that x^3 + 3x^2 + 2x - 6 = (x-1)(x^2+4x+6). So to find the other roots of , we only need to determine the roots of x^2+4x+6 = 0. As a real polynomial, this quadratic factor is irreducible ( has no roots). However, as a complex polynomial, we can use the quadratic formula:
x \amp = \frac{-4 \pm \sqrt{16 - 4 \cdot 1 \cdot 6}}{2} \amp = \frac{-4 \pm \sqrt{-8}}{2} \amp = \frac{-4 \pm \sqrt{-1}\sqrt{2}\sqrt{4}}{2} \amp = -2 \pm \ci\sqrt{2}.
Therefore, the degree-three polynomial equation in
does indeed have precisely three roots: x = -1, -2+\ci\sqrt{2}, -2-\ci\sqrt{2}. And the cubic polynomial in
can be fully factored as x^3 + 3x^2 + 2x - 6 = (x-1)\bbrac{x - (-2+\ci\sqrt{2})}\bbrac{x - (-2-\ci\sqrt{2})}.
